articles.headline: G.M. in Deal With Union as Deadline Approaches
articles.snippet: An agreement with the U.A.W. was a crucial obstacle for G.M. to clear before a June 1 deadline to restructure debt.
articles.abstract: An agreement with the U.A.W. was a crucial obstacle for G.M. to clear before a June 1 deadline to restructure debt.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT  General Motors reached a deal with its union on concessions on Thursday and is now racing the clock to persuade its bondholders to eliminate $27 billion in debt and avoid a bankruptcy filing.

articles.headline: Oil Industry Braces for Trial on Rights Abuses
articles.snippet: Royal Dutch Shell will face charges of crimes against humanity in connection with Nigerian activists’ deaths.
articles.abstract: Royal Dutch Shell will face charges of crimes against humanity in connection with Nigerian activists’ deaths.
articles.lead_paragraph: Fourteen years after the execution of the Nigerian author and activist Ken Saro-Wiwa by Nigeria’s former military regime, Royal Dutch Shell will appear before a federal court in New York to answer charges of crimes against humanity in connection with his death.

articles.headline: A.I.G. Chief, Brought In During Bailout, to Leave
articles.snippet: The Federal Reserve is expected to help in the search for a successor to Edward M. Liddy, who will stay on in the interim.
articles.abstract: The Federal Reserve is expected to help in the search for a successor to Edward M. Liddy, who will stay on in the interim.
articles.lead_paragraph: Edward M. Liddy, the retired insurance executive drafted by the government to lead the American International Group after it nearly collapsed last fall, is stepping down after eight grueling months with virtually no pay.

articles.headline: Tiananmen Now Seems Distant to China’s Students
articles.snippet: Disinclined to protest, students also lack the economic grievances that motivated their predecessors in 1989.
articles.abstract: Disinclined to protest, students also lack the economic grievances that motivated their predecessors in 1989.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING  On April 30, the cellphones of the 32,630 students at Peking University, a genteel institution widely regarded as one of China’s top universities, buzzed with a text message from the school administration. It warned students to “pay attention to your speech and behavior” on Youth Day because of a “particularly complex” situation.

articles.headline: Potential Risk in a Move to Give Investors More Say on Boards
articles.snippet: If a particular rule is adopted, shareholders will get something they have never seen before: ballots with more candidates than jobs to be filled.
articles.abstract: If a particular rule is adopted, shareholders will get something they have never seen before: ballots with more candidates than jobs to be filled.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Securities and Exchange Commission is worried about shareholder democracy.

articles.headline: Obama Faces Pitfalls on Detainees
articles.snippet: President Obama faced criticism from the right for his plan to bring terror suspects to prisons on American soil and from the left for hewing too closely to George Bush’s approach.
articles.abstract: President Obama faced criticism from the right for his plan to bring terror suspects to prisons on American soil and from the left for hewing too closely to George Bush’s approach.
articles.lead_paragraph: As President Obama defends his national security strategy, he faces a daunting challenge. He must convince the country that it is in safe hands despite warnings to the contrary from the right, and at the same time persuade the skeptical left that it is enough to amend his predecessor’s approach rather than abandon it.
